title: 103_hr370
content: The Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 is addressed in Section 1. The Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 applies to individuals in employment positions in the House of Representatives, with remedies and procedures from the Fair Employment Practices Resolution. The House of Representatives can enact rules regarding this application. The Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 applies to employees and applicants of Congress instrumentalities, with establishment of remedies and procedures by the chief official of each instrumentality. After establishing remedies and procedures, the Congress must submit a report describing them. The Fair Labor Standards Act applies to instrumentalities of the Congress. The Fair Labor Standards Act applies to individuals employed by instrumentalities of the Congress, with remedies and procedures established by the chief official of each instrumentality. A report must be submitted to Congress detailing these remedies and procedures, including steps taken by the Architect of the Capitol to implement section 8(b). The Architect of the Capitol must report to Congress on the implementation of section 8(b) of the Fair Labor Standards Amendments of 1989. The House of Representatives recommends reviewing the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 and making recommendations on its application to the House. Judicial review is also addressed. Any individual in an employment position or applying for one, aggrieved by violations of various acts, may petition for review by the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. The House of Representatives should amend its rules regarding payments for judgments against members found guilty by the Federal Circuit. Employees of Congress instrumentalities can seek redress for violations of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967. Employees of Congress instrumentalities can petition for review by the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit following final decisions on violations of various acts such as the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Civil Rights Act of 1991. Employees of Congress instrumentalities can petition for review by the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit within 90 days of receiving a final decision on violations of specific acts. The court will review all legal questions and interpret constitutional and statutory provisions, setting aside decisions deemed arbitrary, capricious, or an abuse of discretion. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit can review decisions on violations of specific acts made by Congress instrumentalities. The court will set aside decisions that are arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, not consistent with law, procedures, or supported by substantial evidence. If the aggrieved individual prevails in an appeal, they may be awarded a reasonable attorney's fee. SEC. 5. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The Americans with Disabilities Act and the Civil Rights Act of 1991 are being amended to update administration and procedures related to fair employment practices and remedies. The Americans with Disabilities Act and the Civil Rights Act of 1991 are being amended to update administration and procedures related to fair employment practices and remedies. The amendments include changes to subsection (a)(2)(B) and section (b)(2) of the Acts. The Americans with Disabilities Act and the Civil Rights Act of 1991 are being amended to update fair employment practices and remedies. SEC. 6 defines key terms. The terms "employment position" and "employing authority" are defined in the Fair Employment Practices Resolution. The Fair Employment Practices Resolution refers to House Resolution 558 of the One Hundredth Congress. The term "instrumentalities of the Congress" includes specific entities like the Architect of the Capitol and the Library of Congress. The term "instrumentalities of the Congress" excludes the Library of Congress for sections 1(b) and 4(b)(1), and excludes the Architect of the Capitol for section 4(b)(4) and subsections (a), (b), and (c) of section 2.
